comment.author: 64342064@N02
comment._content: According to Brooklyn Daily Eagle Almanac from 1890 (http://books.google.com/books?id=qEDOAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=brooklyn+daily+eagle+almanac&hl=en&ei=wPYBTtTPAoTqgQfnuMXJDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false), School No. 1 was at Adams St. and Concord. maps.google.com/maps?q=40.697716,-73.988534&ll=40.697...

comment.author: 64385607@N06
comment._content: This building is in my neighborhood. It is located at 2274 (2274-2286) Church Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. It's a designated landmark building built by architect/civil engineer John Y. Culyer of Flatbush/Prospect Park fame, circa 1878. It was originally PS1 and later was PS90. maps.google.com/maps?q=2323+Church+Ave,+Flatbush+Avenue,+... www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/PS_90.pdf

comment.author: 64385607@N06
comment._content: On the corner of Church Ave + Bedford Ave, Flatbush, Brooklyn

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: On June 22, 2011, TBoni suggested where this photo was taken; thank you for your efforts to #mapBK!

comment.author: 79759083@N00
comment._content: I don't think this is the same building. The old P.S. 90 building at 2274 Church Avenue/2192 Bedford Avenue looks very different from this one.

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
You're right, Flatbush Gardener -- thanks for the picture. It's back to the drawing board for more research on this one. If it's Flatbush PS1, it's definitely not Adams and Concord -- that's the Heights (we're in pre-consolidation Brooklyn here!).

Deb Wythe
Digital Lab

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Unless, of course, we're looking at the back here...
DW

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: As ltrupiano says: let your fingers do the walking (I was proposing an excursion). TBoni's right: here's a picture of the extended building Definitely a match. Thanks, Brownstoner! DW

comment.author: 64385607@N06
comment._content: www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/PS _90.pdf Check out this link - it gives all the details from the Landmarks Preservation Commission. If you scroll down there is a picture of the entire building from 1940. It's definitely the building...it takes up the block right behind Erasmus High.

comment.author: 79473812@N08
comment._content:
The Brainerd image is flipped horizontally.  

I know of one other Brainerd image in the Brooklyn Museum mapBK collection, a photo of Holy Cross Church on Church Ave. also in Flatbush, where I grew up (Holy Cross was my parish) that is also reversed (as I noted on that page).  If these images were printed by Brainerd, himself, he mistakenly flipped the negatives!

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Our fault entirely -- we scanned from negatives. We'll double check and correct. Thanks for the head's up.
Deb Wythe
Brooklyn Museum Digital Lab

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Flipped, as suggested. Thanks for the correction!
Deb Wythe
Brooklyn Museum Digital Lab
